Message.Title: Amazon CreditCard scam--Bezos should be ashamed.
Message.Msg: There is a trick to this "service", and I was surprised that Amazon would associate its name with it. If you buy a large item, you will be offered a promotional rate. That part is not unusual. We all know that ploy: they offer the low rate, hoping to trap you into a higher rate later. But here is the special trick Amazon does not warn you about: Without your knowledge, Amazon will change your default payment method to the new account. You will think your later, normal, charges are going to the credit card you formerly used, but instead they are going to the new Amazon Store Card. The charges are not eligible for the promotional rate, but instead are hit with $26% interest. They hide what they are doing by sending you "paperless statements", which are only emails with no transaction information. Theoretically you can find your true statement on the Internet, but it is devilishly difficult to do so. By the time you learn all this, you may have paid several months of 26% interests on charges you were not aware of. If you complain to Amazon, they will say they have "no involvement with" the Amazon Store Card. They will say that all has to do with General Electric Credit. However, if you can find anyone at General Electric willing to talk to you, they will tell you, correctly, that it is Amazon that changes your default payment option, without your knowledge, and GE cannot control that (not that they mind).

And second-quarter results released in late July by larger rival United Parcel Service Inc. suggested that the global economic slowdown may be even worse than FedEx anticipated.

Topic.Title: Amzn is playing gimicks with margins

Message.Msg: I suspect the biggest "gimmick" at the moment is the build out of fulfillment centers. The stated reason for building these centers is to lower costs and allow for same day delivery. Perhaps. But it appears the primary driver was to settle potential litigation in States that had passed internet sales tax laws and where AMZN was liable for large payments of uncollected sales taxes if sued by each respective State. Hence it was a business decision to negotiate fulfillment centers and jobs instead, while negotiating a delay in the collection of sales taxes in order to protect margins. JMO.

Message.Title: Amzn's accounting
Message.Msg: If an item that AMZN doesn't own is sold off the AMZN site, do they book the gross selling price of the item or just their selling & shipping fees? If they sell inventory they do own (out of their inventory), then it is proper to book all the revenue and then reduce it for COGS.
That's why his knickname is "adummy".

Topic.Title: Oh come on already! Can't we see a negative number?

Message.Msg: And yet earnings will remain stagnant as AMZN overinvests in physical infrastructure. Just as Universities eventually learn that the gift that covers construction doesn't cover operating expense and thus leads to increased OpEx per capita (and thus ballooning tuition costs), so too will AMZN learn... When the transition from "story" to reality begins, this will get rocked. A bunch of low ROIC investments that WS analysts continue to trumpet. This analyst should know better...

I don't believe that you are correct. With 3rd Party sales, the company books only the net revenue, which is one of the reasons that their gross margin is edging up. Both 3P and AWS sales have 100% gross margin. The very real costs that AMZN incurs--technology, credit card processing, etc., are treated (perhaps inappropriately) as general expenses, not COGS.
